review.title: Optimizations for Decision Making and Planning in Description Logic Dynamic Knowledge Bases
review.abstract: Artifact-centric models for business processes recently raised a lot of attention as they manage to combine structural (i.e. data related) with dynamical (i.e. process related) aspects in a seamless way. This developed in parallel with declarative approaches for modelling processes, where activities are not burdened by over-specified constrains like in traditional process-centric approaches, but try to adapt the internal system to the humans involved and the input they receive. In this paper, we try to merge these two aspects by proposing a framework aimed at describing rich business domains through Description Logic-based ontologies, and where a set of actions allows the system to evolve by modifying such ontologies. We then propose an evolution of such framework which represents a viable and formal environment to develop decision making and planning techniques for DL-based artifact-centric business domains.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In fact, such an approach is called into question from two different points of view. First, the only focus on the workflow ignores the informational context in which the workflow is carried out. Second, the traditional approach of defining workflows turns out to be too rigid, burdened by excessive constraints, while in reality the actors who carry out the workflow are still able to break it, while the last point can also be applied to planning.

sections.heading: 2 Dynamic Knowledge Base
sections.text: The Dynamic Knowledge Bases (or DKBs) are, in short, dynamic systems (more precisely, transition systems) in which the states are constituted by DL-Lite knowledge bases consisting of a TBox and an ABox, and a series of actions that further develop the system by modifying the ABox: it follows that the TBox is fixed, while the ABox makes changes by not allowing functional roles, nor allows attributes. The ABox is a finite series of assertions, i.e. atomic formulas of the form C (i) and R (i), in which C is an atomic concept, and i, is an individual constant defined by a particular universe.

sections.heading: 4 Optimizations
sections.text: Considering the specifications of a DKB, few details arise that pose a problem in order to achieve our goal. First, we consider only the totality of the knowledge available at a given time. Although such a condition is necessary to assess the consistency of the overall system, it limits us to work with details that may not be of immediate interest. In decision-making [Gigerenzer and Gaissmaier, 2011], "heuristics is a strategy that ignores a portion of the information, with the goal of making decisions faster, more economical and / or more accurate than more complex methods." For our framework to be used for such strategies, it must be able to work with partial information so that users can focus on a selected subset of knowledge. This goal is crucial when we are dealing with systems described by complex ontologies and composed of millions (if not more) instances. In order to fulfill these goals, we must constitute a transition from the two types of system to the one, not the optimization, and the two types of system to the transition.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: In this essay, we formalize a framework based on descriptive logic and aimed at modelling the dynamics of business processes. Such a framework, called Dynamic Knowledge Bases, is represented by a transitional system in which states are defined by a DL-Lite knowledge base and in which a series of actions allow the system to evolve by adding or removing assertions, along with the ability to introduce new instances. The expressive power and argumentation services of description logic are very helpful in describing and managing domain knowledge, but represent a difficult environment for us to deal with in terms of processes. To address this problem, we introduce two optimizations, namely the rewriting of actions and the abstraction of the transition system in the context of a Dynamic Knowledge Base: These optimizations give us a framework in which we can work with partial knowledge and in which the box does not require a solution, which still guarantees that the framework is more relevant to the decision-making aspect.
